columns.text: In this problem, we need to  list the effects to be considered when deciding on a credit offer, and to explain how the NPV of credit policy change can be  estimated.
**a)**  Effects to consider when deciding on a credit offer are revenue effects, cost effects, the cost of debt, t he probability of nonpayment, and  the cash discount.

**b)** Here we need to explain how to assess changes in NPV in credit policy. 
Assume that the company  has defined price per unit $P$, variable cost per unit $v$, current quantity sold per month $Q$, quantity sold under new policy $Q^{\prime}$, and monthly required return $R$.

Therefore, we see what benefits we have from the change, but at the same time we have other costs. As the quantity sold increases from $Q$ to $Q^{\prime}$, so the costs per unit increase by $v\cdot (Q^{\prime}-Q)$.
 Second cost incurred in these new conditions is that sales that would be collected this month under current policy will not be collected. So, the cost of the switch is 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{Cost of switching }&=P\cdot Q+v\cdot (Q^{\prime}-Q)\\
\end{align*}$$

The NPV of the switch is the present value of the future incremental cash flows reduced by an amount of cost of switching: 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{NPV of switching}&=\frac{(P-v)(Q^{\prime}-Q)}{R}-\left[P\cdot Q+v\cdot (Q^{\prime}-Q)\right]\\
\end{align*}$$

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
